reviewText: I loved this since I first saw it when I was 12. I think it is better than the books, which is more than I can say for a lot of movies that are based on books. If I could change anything I would not have substituted Rachel Lynde in the movie for Mr.Harrison in the book: the scene in the beginning where Anne's cow gets into Rachel's field. For one thing it is sort of inconsistent as Anne and Rachel seemed to have gotten along well after their disagreement with each other when they first meet in the first episode. Also I think they should have included the characters from the book, Paul Irving and Miss Lavender; they were such lovely characters.I enjoyed the Harris family (Emmaline, Pauline, Mrs. Harris and Morgan) but too bad they weren't in the book. Emmaline on the set is the replacement for Elizabeth in the book. I sort of felt sorry for Morgan Harris when he proposed to Anne and she turned him down, but he was obviously not a good choice. She would have been unhappy since he was a womanizer.This is one rare case, though, where the movie turns out better than the book it was based on. This usally doesn't happen, at least in my opinion. I found much of the Anne books with the exception of Anne Of Green Gables, to be incredibly dull. This movie brought out the best!

reviewText: Second of three installments, although at four hours long, it was clearly broadcast by Canadian TV in more than one segment. Not quite as good as the original one I reviewed recently, but very good. This particular sequel was drawn from three of Lucy Maud Montgomer's books, and suffers some from the cutting. Until I see the third one, I will not know if some of the missing parts have been incorporated there, either as events later in Anne's life or as flashbacks. But it certainly has picked out some good stuff. It has also changed some good stuff, and left out a lot of good stuff. Sad, but then it is a large set, seven or eight books, depending on whether you count all the ones which include Anne as a secondary character while her children are growing up.The best part is the time she spent as an English teacher in a snooty private school. I'm not certain here, but I think several elements were borrowed from the time in the books where she was a student in college. The handsome and wealthy older man who pays court to her certainly was, and I think some of the events which took place (falling through the shed roof, for example) in the private school events here were in Avonlea originally.Well, if I say more on that score, I will ruin the movie for you. Let's just say for those who have read the books, don't expect it to match and you will enjoy the story much more. Anne continues her habit of compassion for unlovable people, turning them lovable in the process, and eventually realizes that the same should apply to lovable people. Including, of course, Gilbert Blythe, who is in medical school as the story ends.Since I accidentally ordered the third one before the second one, I happen to know the next movie leaves considerable gap there, but that's OK. Anything left out can indeed be inferred in the first few minutes of the third film, which is how long it took me to realize that I had the third installment and not the second.Even given that this is a completely Canadian story, I'm beginning to think they have a special gift of innocence in storytelling that America used to have. I really am enjoying this series immensely, and suspect most of you would, too.
summary: Not As Good As the First Episode, But Good

reviewText: Have waited for awhile to see this. I ordered it thru blockbuster online and they took forever getting it to me.What a worthless piece of garbage! ...uh, just kidding... This has got to be just about the most wonderful and delightful story ever put on film! I loved every single minute of it. And so will you. It's set in my favorite time period, the 'Edwardian Age'.Anne is like a mature Pollyanna. She brings warmth, caring and sunshine into everyone's life. Her charm and sweetness touch everyone she comes into contact with. But it's in a more realistic way than what Disney portrays.You cannot say enough good about this film. Well, there are a couple of scenes you might have a little difficulty with, one is where her friend throws her dress over her shoulder to walk thru a potato patch, and shows her bloomers...but it's mild compared to what is shown today. Other than that, it's nearly flawless. You'll fall in love with Anne Shirley...i did.She takes a job as a teacher in a girl's college, so girls might like it a bit more than boys. But it's great for the whole family.***** FIVE BIG STARS!
summary: You'll fall in love with Anne Shirley...i did.

reviewText: Megan Follows and Colleen Dewhurst star in the inevitable follow-up to ANNE OF GREEN GABLES - ANNE OF AVONLEA (aka ANNE OF GREEN GABLES THE SEQUEL in Aust. and the UK).Anne decides to spread her wings and leave Avonlea, and takes a teaching position at the Ladies College at Kingsport.  There she comes under scrutiny from the town's oldest family - the formidable Pringles.Having left Gilbert (Jonathan Crombie) in the lurch at Diana Barry's (Schuyler Grant) wedding to Fred Wright, she begins to realise her true feelings for him, and decides she will accept his proposal.After her husband's death, Rachel Lynde (Patricia Hamilton) moves in with Marilla, and Anne is shocked at the news that Gilbert has contracted scarlet fever....A rare case of the sequel matching the original, this new mini series is as delightful as the first.As of this review's writing, the third installment in the series has been made, ANNE OF GREEN GABLES - THE CONTINUING STORY tells of Anne and Gilbert in the first World War.

reviewText: This is the continuing story of Anne of Green Gables (Megan Follows) and proves to be a very strong sequel to the original film.  This time, Anne is a little older and has aspirations to become a teacher, as well as a writer.  This takes her away from Avonlea, in St. Edwards Island, to teach at an all girls preparatory school.  She encounters snobbery as well as a handsome and influential widowed father (Frank Converse) of one of her pupils, and must deal with a very crotchety and almost sinister headmistress (Marilyn Lightstone).  A more grown-up Anne must martial her strength, as well as her patience, in some very trying situations.  All the while, keeping close to her heart the dear family and friends she left behind.Megan Follows is radiant, cast as the title character.  She skillfully and sensitively portrays a more mature Anne with spunk and grace.  The supporting cast is wonderful, here, too, which features the legendary Dame Wendy Hiller as the cold, unfeeling and domineering old grandmother of one of Anne's students.  This is a great family that viewers, young and old, can enjoy together.  This is truly a wonderful film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Anne of Green Gables - The Sequel", also released as "Anne of Avonlea", is the DVD version of Sullivan Entertainment's hugely enjoyable 1987 Canadian television production.  It returns the outstanding cast from "Anne of Green Gables", including Megan Follows as red-haired orphan Anne Shirley, Colleen Dewhurst as Anne's foster mother Marilla Cuthbert, and Jonathan Crombie as Anne's friend and admirer Gilbert Blythe.As the story opens, Anne is the Avonlea schoolmarm and an aspiring writer, but still prone to youthful misadventures.  The occasion of her best friend Diana's wedding brings a fateful reckoning.  Gilbert, grown to admirable young manhood, wants more from Anne than her friendship. Anne, fearful of change and clinging to some romanticized notions, makes an anguished refusal of his proposal. Gilbert departs for medical school while Anne decides to take a teaching position at a young woman's school in Kingsport.  There, she will have to earn her place in the face of haughty students and a hostile administrator.  Anne will respond with enthusiasm, wit, and some subtle guile.  She will become close to the Harris family, and meet a man who seems to fit more closely her notion of romance."The Sequel" borrows elements from the books "Anne of Avonlea", Anne of the Island", and "Anne of Windy Poplars", but recombines them in a new and compressed timeline.  A connecting thread is Anne's relationship with Gilbert.  It is a source of some humor and much dramatic tension that Anne is the one person on PEI who doesn't know that Gilbert is meant to be her soul-mate, and it is her uncertain journey to that knowledge that frames this delightful story."Anne of Green Gables - The Sequel" is very highly recommended to fans of the "Anne of Green Gables" books and the Sullivan Entertainment "Anne" productions.

reviewText: This is a well-produced and written sequel. It is faithful to the original production and to its literary roots in a concise form. I extremely enjoyed it and found it to be a good follow-up to the lives of the central characters from the original ANNE OF GREEN GABLES. The cast was very good and gave very credible and memorable performances. I was very impressed with Frank Converse, an actor I always liked and it was good to see him in a substantial role once again. Megan Follows is once again brilliant and very charismatic as Anne Shirley. The print is very good making the details of the sets and beautiful outdoor photography emerge quite stunning. I highly recommend this one.

reviewText: Megan Follows, Colleen Dewhurst, Jonathan Crombie, Schuyler Grant, Marilyn Lightstone, Rosemary Radcliffe, Robert Collins, Charmion King, Morgan Chapman, Mag Ruffman, Anna Ferguson, Zack Ward, David Hughes, Trish Nettleton, Jennifer Inch and Patrica Hamilton all return in their original roles from the first mini-series film, Anne Of Green Gables (1985).It's been two years since we have seen Anne (Megan Follows) who is a fine 18-year old lady and a schoolteacher.  Anne has been pursuing her desire to get one of her stories published.  In fact, Marilla (Colleen Dewhurst) has become more soft with Anne and has decided to bring in a *new young girl as a border to allow Anne to have time for her other projects.  Anne had written a very personal romance story to which her friend, Diana (Schuyler Grant), had altered a line and added a baking powder product to the story and entered it into a contest without Anne knowing it.  The baking powder sponsors loved it and Anne won the prize, howvever Anne was the last to know and since the whole town knew before she did, Diana finally confessed.Anne also has feelings for Gilbert (Jonathan Crombie), but is afraid to show that in front of him.  First she is polite, then she puts up her guard and gets angry.  At home, she cries to Marilla about her feelings for Gilbert.  Anne is doing the right thing.  Just let time take its course.  Gilbert might have feelings for Anne too.  Of course he does.Not wanting to get too close to Gilbert for now, Anne decides to take the offer of her former schoolteacher, Miss Stacy (Marilyn Lightstone) and meet her in Kingsport to get a more formal study as a schoolteacher.  Teaching in a boarding school of unappreciative students is very hard for Anne, but with the moral support from Miss Stacy, Anne will show the boarding school and its financial contributors she is very much needed there.It is Green Gables she wants to return to...home.Running Time: 3 hours, 49 minutes.A 2002 video release in the United Kingdom runs a little over 4 hours.The third mini-series film was made 12 years later, ANNE OF GREEN GABLES: THE CONTINUING STORY (2000).*The Disney Channel broadcast a new tv series, "ROAD TO AVONLEA" (1989-1996) with Colleen Dewhurst, Patricia Hamilton, Leslie Carlson. Marilyn Lightstone and Anna Ferguson in their original "Anne" roles and with Jackie Burroughs and James O'Regan in different roles.You can buy the first season of the tv series of "Road To Avonlea" on DVD as "TALES FROM AVONLEA", November 8, 2005.Anne of Green Gables: A New Beginning was released on television in December 2008. Kevin Sullivan is the director.Hannah Endicott-Douglas as "young Anne Shirley". Barbara Hershey as "older Anne Shirley", Shirley MacLaine as "Amelia Thomas".

reviewText: My wife and I enjoyed this movie as much as the first even though the story in the movie is taken from happenings in several books.Anne goes off to teach English at a stuffy girls school and quickly finds the Pringle girls, their families, the school board against her, requesting she resign and threaten to stop funding the school.Lesser hearts would give in. Anne tho, knowing she has done nothing wrong, holds her head up high, and joining forces with Mrs Stacey, dream up an ingenious scheme to turn things around. See the movie to see how she does it. This is a wonderful tale of the triumph of the human spirit.Anne has the knack of being able to influence those around her and win over the hearts of those who dislike her. The nasty Pringle clan who tried to oust her will sing her praises. The hateful Pringle girls in her class grow to love and respect her. Even the stern school superintendent's life is changed by Anne. And it's fun to see the old Mrs Harris grow to trust Anne and enjoy life finally.I'd give both of the movies 10 stars if possible. Ignore the low rating on some of the reviews - curmugeons!!

reviewText: I loved this movie because the characters and the scenery are just wonderful. I have read all of the Anne books by LM Montgomery except for the first one (Anne of Green Gables)which I saw the movie on PBS and Rainbow Valley which was more about the Meredith Family so I skipped it. I thought Kevin Sullivan did a masterful job of combining elements from three of the books together for this film. The movie starts out with Anne leaving Green Gables PEI to teach at a private girls school in Nova Scotia. The girls are rich and bratty but Anne of course wins them over. My favorite part of this film, however, is when Anne realizes her love for Gilbert Blythe. Both Megan Follows and Jonathan Crombie are brilliantly cast in their roles as the lovestruck twosome. If you want to escape to another era and see what life was like then this film will take you away and entertain you all at the same time.

reviewText: Anne, the Sequel, is a great movie.  It has the same characters as in the first movie with some new ones added in.  The actors all do a great job, especially Megan Follows and Jonathan Crombie, in making their characters come to life.  The chemistry between Megan Follows and Jonathan Crombie is great. This is a movie for the family to watch.  It is a movie that displays values and morals.  This is a feel good movie to be watched over and over.  A must-have for anyone's collection.

reviewText: "Anne of Avonlea" is a brilliant companion to the original "Anne of Green Gables."  This sequel combines the next THREE novels in the series --- "Anne of Avonlea," "Anne of the Island," and "Anne of Windy Poplars."  Several characters are combined to make ONE specific character, but the story still remains very much Anne's story.Now a little older, having taught at the public school in Avonlea for a while, Anne decides to try her hand at teaching at a private school in Kingsport --- a wealthy town mainly run by a particular set, the Pringles.  It's a new and daunting experience --- especially considering that she can't seem to win over the students or the school board --- but her stubbornnes won't allow her to give up, and she charges forward with her usual determination.There are several new characters, but we still have appearances by the old ones.  We meet Morgan Harris, his intelligent daughter Emmeline, his mother and his sister, and of course we meet countless girls who go to Kingsport Ladies College.  But Rachel Lynde and Marilla Cuthbert are still around, Diana Barry remains a wonderful friend, and of course there is the wonderful Gilbert Blythe --- more in love with Anne than ever.This is one of the best sequels I have ever seen, it fits perfectly with the original movie and does a decent job of remaining as faithful as possible to the books, in spite of everything that was altered.  I love this movie.  To this day, my family occasionally has "Anne Weekends," in which we watch "Anne of Green Gables" one night and "Anne of Avonlea" the next!
summary: Equally as charming as the first one

reviewText: The original mini-series of "Anne of Green Gables" ended with Anne (Megan Follows) on speaking terms with Gilbert (Jonathan Crombie), but still the only person in Avonlea who does not know that the two of them are meant to live happily ever after.  "Anne of Green Gables" is adapted by writer-director Kevin Sullivan from the second, third, and fourth novels in the series, drawing primarily on the last one, "Anne of Windy Poplars" for her experiences teaching at a girl's school.  There is also a major subplot regarding a rich widower who seems to offer Anne everything she has ever wanted that is largely Sullivan's creation; Morgan Harris (Frank Converse) is much older than Anne's other beau in the series.  The important thing is that he keeps the ending of "Anne of the Island."I am sure most of you love all of the Anne books and the first two films, which means the issue is why you should also pick up the DVD versions. The answer is simply the director's commentary. There are a few missing scenes, several of which are alternative takes, and some behinds the scenes still photographs, but the chief charm here is listening to director Kevin Sullivan talk to the film's editor about the production (she does not have much to say; I think she was there to give Sullivan a real person to talk to during the almost four hour film). From this commentary you will learn where many of the scenes were shot on PEI but mostly around Toronto (we tracked down several of them on the journey home from PEI, including THE BRIDGE), what he took (and why) from the three Lucy Maud Montgomery novels this film was based on, Dame Wendy Hiller's accident that almost made her quit the film and the scene she insisted Sullivan shoot for her, and loads of other fascinating little details about the production and the performances.This is certainly an above average commentary track and fans of the film will not be disappointed. It would be nice if the DVD features closed-captioning, which I like to turn on while doing the director's commentary, but despite this rather odd omission, I think fans will enjoy this addition to their collection. Besides, it is not like we have not already pretty much memorized the entire show.  Final Note: If you watch the opening scene of "Anne of of Green Gables: The Sequel" or whatever it is being called this time around) you will see Anne Shirley bicycle by Dalvay by the Sea, the "White Sands" hotel from the "Avonlea" series. I mention this because I stayed at the hotel for a couple of days at the start of my honeymoon on PEI, where I picked up both of the "Anne" DVDs after seeing the musical version of "Anne of Green Gables" in Charlottetown.
summary: I know you already own this, but you want the commentary

reviewText: The movie is neat because it shows how Anne can take any given experience and shift it into something positive and good. She is dealt many problems yet she turns them into gold. She is a beautiful poised imaginative girl who is growing up. She draws people to her and they change by knowing her. I loved the fun she had in the snow on the steamer and ice skating with people who were happy, I would love to be in a play, I love Anne's relationship with Murilla and especially her finally realizing how much she loved Gilbert Bly.

reviewText: Several things contribute to confusion in the U.S. about this excellent Canadian mini-series, the sequel to the beloved award-winningAnne of Green Gables". One is that when originally aired in the states it was under the name "Anne of Avonlea". Another is that the third project in the series, Anne Of Green Gables - The Continuing Story, is so bad I honestly felt a sickening sensation watching the inept degradation of these characters.Megan Follows returns as Anne Shirley, now graduated from college and taking a position teaching at a girl's school in Kingsport, Nova Scotia. Colleen Dewhurst returns as Marilla Cuthbert, back home at Green Gables on Prince Edward Island. Schuyler Grant and Jonathan Crombie return as bosom friend Diana Barry and nemesis-love interest Gilbert Blythe.In Kingsport Anne's determined spirit, honest compassion and ability to win over the stoniest hearts serve her well as she meets feisty girls at the school as well as stern headmistresses and wealthy old families who initially want to knock the fight out of our Anne.Drawn from Montgomery's 2nd, 3rd and 4th books, Kevin Sullivan also introduces new characters and storylines which do not distract.So - get thee a copy of "Anne of Green Gables" and follow it up with this fine production. Pity that Kevin Sullivan can't leave a good thing alone and felt compelled to also produce the nauseating third installment.
summary: The Excellent Second of the Series - Not the Awful Third
Title: N/A

reviewText: I mainly have known this story to be Anne of Avonlea. I also might add I haven't the pleasure of reading L. M. Montgomery book series of Anne of Green Gables. But this has been one of the best sequels I have ever seen. The new additions to the cast is great. We still follow the life of Anne Shirley as she matures and intends on graduating college and becoming a teacher, and a writer. She also has to help with Green Gables now that Mathew is gone. Her friendship also blossom's with Gilbert B. however, she isn't ready to fall in love with him yet. As it becomes a hard decision she is comfortable with Marilla living with Rachel at Green Gables as she goes off to teach at a private girls school which is a new chapter and new adventures. She then becomes involved with a young girl Emmeline Harris and falls into a very close relationship with her father Morgan Harris. She makes the town fall in love with her despite them disliking new comer's to the town. However, she realizes that she is very much home sick and that she belongs back home in Green Gables and she also realizes that her and Gilbert belong together. Again it's always fantastic to see all of the actor's and characters return to this amazing sequel. There are a few characters very much missed, but remembered in this film. And all of the relationships between Anne and her friends grow stronger and stronger. The new additions are just as wonderful with the private school and the other characters of the new town. It really is a wonderful piece and a nice conclusion to this series. The DVD quality I guess some have complained about, but I don't see anything wrong with it. It has all of the same extra's, except in a new version with this sequel that the first DVD set had. Again I highly recommend this for any Anne fan.

reviewText: Adapting a book can be hard to do well - staying true to the characters people already love is, to me, the most important thing.  This film, while it combines plots from 3 books, does a good job of keeping most of the best moments, combining minor characters in a believable way and staying true to the characters LM Montgomery created.  It works well, and will be enjoyed by fans of the books and fans of the Sullivan's "Anne of Green Gables" alike.  (As oppsed to "The Continuing Story" - if you like these movies, trust me, stop with this one!!)

reviewText: I never knew this part of the adaptation did not follow the books as closely as the first part did, until I started reading the books. But that doesn't seem to matter, as the story is charming, engaging and heart-warming!The writer/director does a great job weaving the charm of LMM's middle "Anne books" with his own artistic vision for Anne and we end up with a breathtakingly romantic story, full of love, proposals and new adventures in an urban setting, a perfect challenge for Anne! We get a true-to-spirit adaptation, with worthy embellishment all over.I love the trials Anne's heart faces, as she leaves her beloved Avonlea and heads off to Kingsport to teach a bunch of spoiled, bratty, rich girls English, and ends up slowly winning their hearts, and making friends among them. She also ends up with more proposals than she ever imagined!The acting is superb. Glances and facial expressions end up saying much more than words ever could, and the director wisely lets these do so.Most of the actors are so young, yet so true to character and convincing in their roles, that we are effortlessly swept away into the fantastic world of Anne and her beloved Avonlea.The character changes are reluctant, yet stark. And the costumes and hair just keep getting better (and fluffier, in Anne's case)! The truth is, as the commentary points out, that underneath these splendid dresses and outfits, are some very young, naive children, and they are forced to face the changing world and the world of "growing up".What, too, is wonderful to behold is the past world of Turn-of-the-Century Kingsport, with its "modern conveniences", such as the Steam Engine, electrical bells, and new Telephones, even motor vehicles! - things that PEI does not yet have!The commentary is good, if a bit slow. The director/writer (forgive my lack of using his name) lets us in on behind the scenes info, as well as his inspiration for the changes. And they all work. So, good job, and good commentary.This series is sheer Happiness all over. A sure favorite for still many many generations more.A worthy purchase.

reviewText: I love Anne of Green Gables the Sequel (actually Anne of Avonlea).  Megan Follows did a great job as Anne Shirley the temperamental redhead who aspires to be a teacher and writer.  The movie itself is one of my all-time favorites and if you want it on DVD, it's worth it to get it.That said, the transfer is one of the poorest I've laid eyes on.  It comes in only a 2.0 soundtrack, doesn't even make a virtual center channel or subwoofer like other 2.0 DVDs do and the picture is a bit grainy and I detect a pulsing in the background.  Also it's in fullscreen pan and scan format instead of anamorphic which reduces the resolution to about that of a VHS.  That said, it does have a good menu with extras including some deleted scenes.Overall, if you're looking to get it on DVD go ahead and get it, but don't expect great DVD quality.

reviewText: The first film of this series is one of the best TV productions that I ever saw:  the emotion, yearning, and hope are so raw and real that I weep every time I see it.  This one brings Anne into early adulthood, when she faces challenges outside of school, in the working world, where politics and personal bitterness are difficult realities.  As it turns out, realistically, she has become an extraordinarily fecund person, a protean creator who can win over people and take big chances when necessary.  She triumphs in work and love, as in the novels, but it begins to be rather over the top.  Anne is too saintly, bringing people in as "kindred spirits" in ways that are ridiculously unrealistic.  Some people cannot be reached and there are real tragedies and injustices, but none of that has a place here.  Sure, the drama essentially works - it never becomes stupidly precious - but it is a clear sign that the series really shouldn't go farther.Recommended, but resist the temptation to get the nest equal, the "continuing story", which genuinely and completely fails.
summary: the spirit carries over, but it makes her too saintly
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a wonderful sequel to the film "Anne of Green Gables". In this movie Anne Shirley has graduated from college and is now a schoolteacher in Avonlea. She's still the same independent and strong-minded Anne we have come to know and love. She's older and more mature now and faces new obstacles that include dealing with extremely difficult and arrogant people, her struggles to become a writer and the adjustments she has to make to a new teaching position at a prestigious girl's college. As we witness Anne's travails in life and love, we can clearly see that despite these obstacles, she will survive because she is a resilient, independent and resourceful young woman who should be admired for her strong character and good nature. This is a wonderful follow up that will be fun for the entire family! Megan Follows is unforgettable in her role as Anne Shirley, she is a truly gifted actress that makes the character of Anne come to life in a way we will always remember. Colleen Dewhurst is superb as always as the stern but loving Marilla Cuthbert. With a great script, excellent performances by the lead and supporting casts, and a beautiful, picturesque setting, Anne of Avonlea is a true classic! Highly recommended. Also recommended is of course, "Anne of Green Gables".

reviewText: "Anne of Green Gables - The Sequel" DVD contains the series known on VHS as "Anne of Avonlea."Here, we seen many changes in Avonlea.  Diana Barry is getting married and Gilbert Blythe leaves for medical school.  Anne also leaves Prince Edward Island to teach at a girls school.  Here, she meets the combatative Pringle clan and the dashing Morgan Harris.  Being Anne, she is soon in the thick of mischief and intrigue leading a life of poetry and romance.  All the while charming tears from stones with her honesty and pluck.The cast does it's usual excellent job and "Anne of Green Gables - The Sequel" is every bit the equal to the original "Anne of Green Gables."  The scenery is plush, and the dialog is full of wit and wisdom.The DVD itself is not of superior quality, but it is no worse than a VHS tape (minus one star for DVD quality).  I did not find my enjoyment of the story to be affected in anyway.  It is nice to have the entire series on a single DVD.  This series is a classic to be handed down and enjoyed.
Title: N/A
